messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 58 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: On polynomially many queries to NP or QMA oracles

Paper Abstract: Abstract We study the complexity of problems solvable in deterministic polynomial time with access to an NPNP\mathrm{NP} or Quantum Merlin-Arthur (QMAQMA\mathrm{QMA})-oracle, such as PNPsuperscriptPNP\mathrm{P}^{\mathrm{NP}} and PQMAsuperscriptPQMA\mathrm{P}^{\mathrm{QMA}}, respectively. The former allows one to classify problems more finely than the Polynomial-Time Hierarchy (PHPH\mathrm{PH}), whereas the latter characterizes physically motivated problems such as Approximate Simulation (APX−SIMAPXSIM\mathrm{APX\mathchar 45\relax{}SIM}) [Ambainis, CCC 2014]. In this area, a central role has been played by the classes PNP​[log]superscriptPNPdelimited-[]\mathrm{P}^{\mathrm{NP}[\log]} and PQMA​[log]superscriptPQMAdelimited-[]\mathrm{P}^{\mathrm{QMA}[\log]}, defined identically to PNPsuperscriptPNP\mathrm{P}^{\mathrm{NP}} and PQMAsuperscriptPQMA\mathrm{P}^{\mathrm{QMA}}, except that only logarithmically many oracle queries are allowed. Here, [Gottlob, FOCS 1993] showed that if the adaptive queries made by a PNPsuperscriptPNP\mathrm{P}^{\mathrm{NP}} machine have a “query graph” which is a tree, then this computation can be simulated in PNP​[log]superscriptPNPdelimited-[]\mathrm{P}^{\mathrm{NP}[\log]}. In this work, we first show that for any verification class C∈{NP,MA,QCMA,QMA,QMA​(2),NEXP,QMAexp}𝐶NPMAQCMAQMAQMA2NEXPsubscriptQMAexpC\in\{\mathrm{NP},\mathrm{MA},\mathrm{QCMA},\mathrm{QMA},\mathrm{QMA}(2),\allowbreak\mathrm{NEXP},\mathrm{QMA}_{\mathrm{exp}}\}, any PCsuperscriptPC\mathrm{P}^{\textup{C}} machine with a query graph of “separator number” s𝑠s can be simulated using deterministic time exp⁡(s​log⁡n)𝑠𝑛\exp(s\log n) and s​log⁡n𝑠𝑛s\log n queries to a C𝐶C-oracle. When s∈O​(1)𝑠𝑂1s\in O(1) (which includes the case of O​(1)𝑂1O(1)-treewidth, and thus also of trees), this gives an upper bound of PC​[log]superscriptPCdelimited-[]\mathrm{P}^{\textup{C}[\log]}, and when s∈O​(logk⁡(n))𝑠𝑂superscript𝑘𝑛s\in O(\log^{k}(n)), this yields bound QPC​[logk+1]superscriptQP𝐶delimited-[]superscript𝑘1\mathrm{QP}^{C[\log^{k+1}]} (QPQP\mathrm{QP} meaning quasi-polynomial time). We next show how to combine Gottlob’s “admissible-weighting function” framework with the “flag-qubit” framework of [Watson, Bausch, Gharibian, 2020], obtaining a unified approach for embedding PCsuperscriptPC\mathrm{P}^{\textup{C}} computations directly into APX−SIMAPXSIM\mathrm{APX\mathchar 45\relax{}SIM} instances in a black-box fashion. Finally, we formalize a simple no-go statement about polynomials (c.f. [Krentel, STOC 1986]): Given a multi-linear polynomial p𝑝p specified via an arithmetic circuit, if one can “weakly compress” p𝑝p so that its optimal value requires m𝑚m bits to represent, then PNPsuperscriptPNP\mathrm{P}^{\mathrm{NP}} can be decided with only m𝑚m queries to an NP-oracle.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 58 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 58"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "StoqMA vs. MA: the power of error reduction",
        "Hamiltonian Complexity in the Thermodynamic Limit",
        "On Physical Problems that are Slightly More Difficult than QMA",
        "Approximation Algorithms for Treewidth",
        "Merlin-Arthur Games and Stoquastic Complexity",
        "Bounded queries to SAT and the Boolean hierarchy",
        "On truth-table reducibility to SAT",
        "A General Method for Solving Divide-and-Conquer Recurrences",
        "On the power of probabilistic polynomial time: PNP​[log]⊆PPsuperscriptPNPdelimited-[]PP\\mathrm{P}^{\\mathrm{NP}[\\log]}\\subseteq\\mathrm{PP}",
        "An O​(ck​n)𝑂superscript𝑐𝑘𝑛O(c^{k}n) 5-Approximation Algorithm for Treewidth",
        "Approximating Treewidth, Pathwidth, Frontsize, and Shortest Elimination Tree",
        "A linear time algorithm for finding tree-decompositions of small treewidth",
        "QMA-complete problems",
        "Complexity classification of local Hamiltonian problems",
        "The complexity of theorem-proving procedures",
        "The complexity of theorem proving procedures",
        "The Complexity of the Separable Hamiltonian Problem",
        "Characterizations of some complexity classes between Ω2psuperscriptsubscriptΩ2𝑝\\Omega_{2}^{p} and Δ2psuperscriptsubscriptΔ2𝑝\\Delta_{2}^{p}",
        "The Power of Quantum Systems on a Line",
        "The Quantum and classical complexity of translationally invariant tiling and Hamiltonian problems",
        "Quantum Merlin Arthur with Exponentially Small Gap",
        "Quantum Hamiltonian Complexity",
        "COMPUTERS and INTRACTABILITY: A Guide to the Theory of NP-Completeness",
        "Hardness of approximation for quantum problems",
        "NP trees and Carnap’s modal logic",
        "Oracle Complexity Classes and Local Measurements on Physical Hamiltonians",
        "On balanced separators, treewidth, and cycle rank",
        "The complexity of simulating local measurements on quantum systems",
        "Sparse Complete Sets for NP and the Optimal Collapse of the Polynomial Hierarchy",
        "Some optimal inapproximability results",
        "The strong exponential hierarchy collapses",
        "Exact analysis of Dodgson elections: Lewis Carroll’s 1876 voting system is complete for parallel access to NP",
        "Testing product states, quantum Merlin-Arthur games and tensor optimisation",
        "The Local Hamiltonian problem on a line with eight states is QMA-complete",
        "Reducibility among Combinatorial Problems",
        "The Complexity of the Local Hamiltonian Problem",
        "3-local Hamitonian is QMA-complete",
        "The complexity of optimization problems",
        "Generalizations of Opt P to the polynomial hierarchy",
        "Classical and Quantum Computation",
        "Universal search problems",
        "Universal sequential search problems",
        "On promise problems: A survey",
        "Hamiltonian complexity",
        "On the complexity of unique solutions",
        "Two remarks on the power of counting",
        "Finding approximate separators and computing tree width quickly",
        "Graph minors. II. Algorithmic aspects of tree-width",
        "Oracle Separation of BQP and PH",
        "BQP and the polynomial hierarchy",
        "Oracle Circuits for Branching-Time Model Checking",
        "IP = PSPACE",
        "The polynomial-time hierarchy",
        "More complicated questions about maxima and minima, and some closures of NP",
        "Bounded query computations",
        "The Complexity of Approximating Critical Points of Quantum Phase Transitions",
        "The Complexity of Translationally Invariant Problems beyond Ground State Energies",
        "Computational Complexity of the Ground State Energy Density Problem"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 58 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in On polynomially many queries to NP or QMA oracles, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
